intro: Pimpinella saxifraga var. tevennensis, commonly known as the Alpine parsley, is a member of the Apiaceae family and is native to the mountainous regions of Europe. It is a perennial herb characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and small, yellowish-white flowers that bloom in early summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often in alpine or subalpine habitats. It is adapted to cold climates and can tolerate harsh environmental conditions. Due to its ornamental value and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
